results.summary: A homeless man who admitted the manslaughter of two Big Issue sellers is detained for life with a minimum tariff of 12 years.
results.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/6b409ced-9287-bd4f-b6b2-7db9965c8627"><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="70497762">    <caption>Footage released by police shows killer John Ward befriending his victims</caption>  </video><paragraph role="introduction">A homeless man who admitted killing two Big Issue sellers in a knife attack in Birmingham has been detained for life.</paragraph><paragraph>Ian Watson-Gladwish, 31, and Wayne Busst, 32, who were also homeless, <!-- CPS Asset ID: 24542701 --><link><caption>were stabbed in Union Street on 11 January</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-21045520"/></link>.</paragraph><paragraph>John Ward denied murder but admitted manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility and was given a minimum tariff of 12 years.</paragraph><paragraph>Ward, 23, a paranoid schizophrenic, appeared via video link at Birmingham Crown Court because of safety concerns.</paragraph><paragraph>The court heard that a week ago Ward attacked and seriously injured a member of staff at Ashworth Hospital, the secure psychiatric unit where he is being held.</paragraph><image id="70492550"/><paragraph>Ahead of Ward's trial, Big Issue founder John Bird said "the streets are incredibly dangerous" and it was difficult to protect the magazine vendors.</paragraph><paragraph>He said the charity was looking at other ways of working with homeless people who did not want to be street sellers.</paragraph><paragraph>Both men were stabbed to death near their pitches.</paragraph><paragraph>One of the men was stabbed outside Sainsbury's in Union Street, while the other was found slumped nearby outside a side entrance to Boots.</paragraph><paragraph>Peter Grieves-Smith, prosecuting, said Ward travelled from London to Birmingham, bought a knife, alcohol and a bag of heroin - which he smoked - and then stood with the men as they sold the magazine.</paragraph><crosshead>Fled to cinema</crosshead><paragraph>It was the first time he had met the men, who were fellow drug-users.</paragraph><paragraph>Ward, of no fixed address, then struck out at them, with one eyewitness describing seeing him afterwards looking "angry and arrogant".</paragraph><image id="70490036"/><paragraph>The knife was thrown away in an alleyway and Ward walked to a nearby Odeon cinema where he sat and wiped blood from his face and hands with napkins until the police arrived to arrest him.</paragraph><paragraph>Afterwards he gave police with a written statement that said: "John Ward admits stabbing two men in Birmingham city centre - he intended to hurt them but not to kill them."</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Grieves-Smith said psychiatric experts for both the prosecution and defence had since assessed Ward as a paranoid schizophrenic and agreed that this serious mental health disorder was at the root of his attacks.</paragraph><paragraph>Ward told Dr Panchu Xavier, forensic psychiatrist at Ashworth Hospital, "he didn't want to do anything but "the voices wanted me to kill everyone"'.</paragraph></body>
